Situation1: They sketch a small renovation layout for a personal studio, focusing on basic usability.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story:
I sat at my desk, pencil in hand, sketching a simple renovation layout for my small studio. As an architect, I knew the importance of designing functional spaces, even if it was just for myself. I wanted every corner to serve a purpose, every line to make sense. But my mind kept drifting to the volunteer work I had agreed to do that afternoon. I was supposed to sort through files at the community clinic, each one filled with private medical histories. The expectation was clear: respect the privacy and confidentiality of every person whose name appeared on those pages.

As I drew, I realized I needed to reference some accessibility standards. I remembered that one of the files I’d seen earlier contained details about a client with unique mobility needs—details that would make my design more inclusive. But I also knew that using that information, even with good intentions, would be a breach of trust. The weight of both roles pressed on me: the architect in me wanted to create the best possible space, but the volunteer in me was bound by a promise of confidentiality. My pencil hovered over the page, my thoughts tangled in the expectations pulling me in opposite directions.
